privacyLaws.lawName: Federal Law on Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties
privacyLaws.description: The Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties in Mexico, commonly referred to as the 'Ley Federal de Protección de Datos Personales en Posesión de los Particulares' (LFPDPPP), is a comprehensive legal framework designed to regulate the processing of personal data by private entities operating in Mexico. Enacted in 2010, the law aims to safeguard the privacy of individuals by establishing principles for the lawful collection, use, storage, and disclosure of personal data.

notice.description: The privacy notice required under the Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties in Mexico must include specific information to inform individuals about the processing of their personal data. Firstly, it should clearly state the identity and address of the data controller responsible for collecting the data. Secondly, it must outline the purposes for which the data will be processed, providing transparency about how the information will be used. Additionally, the notice should detail the options and mechanisms available to data subjects to limit the use or disclosure of their data. It must also specify the procedures for individuals to exercise their rights of access, rectification, cancellation, or objection in accordance with the law. If data transfers are planned, the notice must disclose this information. Lastly, the notice should explain how any changes to the privacy notice will be communicated to data subjects, ensuring ongoing transparency and compliance with legal requirements.

purposeLimitation.description: Processing of personal data must be limited to fulfillment of the purposes set out in the privacy notice. If the data controller intends to process data for another purpose which is not compatible or analogous to the purposes set out in the privacy notice, the data owner's consent must be obtained again

dataMinimization.description: Processing of personal data will be done as necessary, appropriate and relevant with relation to the purposes set out in the privacy notice. In particular, for sensitive personal data, the data controller must make reasonable efforts to limit the processing period thereof to the minimum required.

securityReqs.description: All responsible parties that process personal data must establish and maintain physical and technical administrative security measures designed to protect personal data from damage, loss, alteration, destruction or unauthorized use, access or processing.

privacyByDesign.description: In all processing of personal data, it is presumed that there is a reasonable expectation of privacy, understood as the trust any one person places in another for personal data provided to be treated pursuant to any agreement of the parties in the terms established by this Law.

processorReqs.description: The data controller shall ensure compliance with the personal data protection principles established by this Law, and shall adopt all necessary measures for their application. The foregoing will apply even when this data has been processed by a third party at the request of the data controller. The data controller must take all necessary and sufficient action to ensure that the privacy notice given to the data owner is respected at all times by it or by any other parties with which it has any legal relationship.

riskImpact.description: Data controllers will not adopt security measures inferior to those they keep to manage their own information. Moreover, risk involved, potential consequences for the data owners, sensitivity of the data, and technological development will be taken into account.

breachNotification.description: Security breaches occurring at any stage of processing that materially affect the property or moral rights of data owners will be reported immediately by the data controller to the data owner, so that the latter can take appropriate action to defend its rights.

dpo.description: All data controllers must designate a personal data person or department who will process requests from data owners for the exercise of the rights referred to in this Law. In addition, data controllers will promote protection of personal data within their organizations

dataTransfer.description: Data controllers that intend to transfer personal data must provide recipients with the privacy notice and specify the purposes to which the data owner has limited data processing. The transfer must adhere to the terms agreed upon in the privacy notice, which should include a clause indicating whether the data owner agrees to the transfer. Furthermore, the recipient third party is obligated to assume the same responsibilities as the data controller that transferred the data. Article 37 outlines cases where domestic or international transfers of data may be carried out without the consent of the data owner, including transfers pursuant to laws or treaties, transfers necessary for medical purposes, transfers within the same corporate group, transfers pursuant to contractual obligations, transfers for public interest or legal requirements, transfers for judicial proceedings, and transfers necessary to maintain or fulfill a legal relationship between the data controller and the data owner.

exemptions.description: Credit reporting companies under the Law Regulating Credit Reporting Companies and other applicable laws
Persons carrying out the collection and storage of personal data that is exclusively for personal use, and without purposes of disclosure or commercial use

enforcementAuthority: The National Institute of Transparency for Access to Information and Personal Data Protection
finingAuthority: The National Institute of Transparency for Access to Information and Personal Data Protection
penalties: Violations of the Federal Law on Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties will result in penalties administered by the Institute as outlined in Article 64. For cases described in section I of the preceding article, where the data controller fails to comply with actions requested by the data owner, a warning will be issued. In cases falling under sections II to VII, fines ranging from 100 to 160,000 days of the Mexico City minimum wage will be imposed. For violations described in sections VIII to XVIII, fines will range from 200 to 320,000 days of the Mexico City minimum wage. In cases of repeated violations, an additional fine ranging from 100 to 320,000 days of the current Mexico City minimum wage may be imposed. Sanctions for violations involving sensitive data may be increased up to double the established amounts.
privateRightOfAction: Not explicitly granted but it is impolied that a data owner has the right of action.

threshold.description: The parties regulated under this Law are private parties, whether individuals or private legal entities, that process personal data.

otherPrivacyLaws.description: The Privacy Notice Guidelines in Mexico outline the requirements for the content and dissemination of privacy notices, ensuring compliance with the Federal Law on Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties. These guidelines specify that privacy notices must contain certain information, including the identity and domicile of the data controller, purposes of data processing, options for data owners to limit data use or disclosure, means for exercising data rights, details of data transfers, and procedures for notifying data owners of changes to the privacy notice.

otherPrivacyLaws.lawName: The General Law for the Protection of Personal Data in Possession of Obligated Subjects (Ley General de Protección de Datos Personales en Posesión de Sujetos Obligados)
